Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: They must verify that a high-rise hospital project fully complies with all safety regulations to prevent life-threatening hazards.
Story: I stood at the edge of the skate park, phone pressed to my ear, blueprints spread across my lap. My stepbrother, Jamie, was tightening his helmet, eyes gleaming with excitement as he eyed the steep, cracked ramp. “Watch this, I’m finally going to land it!” he called. My heart pounded. As his step-sibling, I was supposed to look out for him, to make sure he didn’t get hurt. But my phone buzzed again—my project manager, reminding me that the final safety inspection for the hospital was in an hour. As the architect, I was responsible for every detail, every regulation, every life that would depend on that building’s safety. I glanced at Jamie, then at the structural notes in my hand. If I left now, I could double-check the fire exits and make sure the stairwells were up to code. But if I left Jamie alone, what if he fell? My mind raced, torn between the brother who trusted me to watch over him and the hundreds of patients who would trust the building I designed. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, demanding I choose.
